awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  SG:  Phylogenomics and diversification of the snapping shrimp genus Alpheus
awd_abstract_narration:
Snapping shrimp in the genus Alpheus, known for their spectacular color patterns and the explosive snap created by their major claw, are one of the most diverse and abundant animal groups in tropical coral reefs. Snapping shrimp form mutualistic relationships with a diversity of partners such as corals and fish and are emerging as a model group for understanding symbiosis and species diversification in marine environments. However, such studies require a more complete understanding of how many different species of Alpheus exist worldwide, and the relationships among these species. This research will address these questions by building an evolutionary tree of the group with next-generation DNA sequencing data. These data will be used to test whether factors such as host symbioses or color patterns drove the spectacular diversification of this group. Studying the biodiversity of this group will help to understand more broadly the origins and maintenance of biodiversity in shallow marine tropical ecosystems. Species pages will be created through the Encyclopedia of Life for public outreach and educational purposes, and a partnership with a science museum will develop workshops in science communication for undergraduates. A graduate student, and multiple undergraduates will also be trained in genetic barcoding, species delimitation, species descriptions, and comparative evolutionary analyses.  
	
This research will produce the first comprehensive global phylogeny of snapping shrimp in the genus Alpheus, spanning >50% of the 300+ described species and using phylogenomic data generated via anchored hybrid enrichment. This phylogeny will be used to test long-standing taxonomic and morphological questions in Alpheus, such as the monophyly of morphologically defined species groups and the role of habitat use in driving instances of morphological convergence. A comprehensive genetic barcoding survey of field and museum specimens will help estimate the existing worldwide biodiversity of the group. Using phylogenetic reconstructions, fieldwork, and color pattern analyses, researchers will test whether color patterns - long hypothesized to have systematic importance - are important factors in establishing species boundaries. Finally, the phylogenomic tree and data on worldwide patterns of species diversity will be used to test whether species diversification in Alpheus is linked to ecological factors such as symbiosis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Outcomes Report: Collaborative Research on Phylogenomics and Diversification in Snapping Shrimp


            This project aimed to investigate the evolutionary relationships, biodiversity, and ecological interactions within the diverse snapping shrimp genus Alpheus. These shrimp, known for their remarkable snapping claws and wide variety of symbiotic relationships, have long been a model for studying speciation, color variation, and marine symbiosis. Despite their importance, a comprehensive worldwide evolutionary tree for Alpheus had been lacking. Our project objectives were as follows:

  1. Construct a comprehensive phylogenomic tree of Alpheus to test taxonomic and morphological hypotheses.
  2. Estimate global species-level biodiversity within Alpheus.
  3. Examine whether specialized host symbiosis impacts diversification rates in Alpheus.

We obtained tissue samples from >200 Alpheus shrimps collected from tropical marine habitats worldwide. Our samples were selected to represent all major species groups in the genus Alpheus and a diversity of ecological niches and symbiotic associations. Tissue samples were obtained from museum collections, including the Florida Museum of Natural History, the National Museum of Natural History in France, and the Oxford University Museum of Natural History in England, as well as from field collections we conducted in Guam in 2022. We used next-generation sequencing to generate the most extensive evolutionary tree for Alpheus to date. Our dataset consisted of ~400 nuclear genes from 147 specimens. This data was successfully combined with sequence alignments from an earlier phylogenomic study, for a total of 212 taxa. Phylogenetic reconstructions revealed 11 major clades corresponding to morphological species groups and illuminated how Alpheus species repeatedly adapted to specialized habitats such as deep-sea environments, burrowing, and rock excavation. This foundational tree is expected to guide future research on the evolution and ecology of these organisms.

As part of this project, we also examined the role of morphological adaptations in facilitating species diversification, focusing on the cryptic species complex Alpheus gracilipes. We applied geometric morphometric techniques to quantitatively examine the claw and rostrum structures of closely related species. Morphological results supported evidence from mitochondrial gene tree reconstructions of two additional cryptic species. This study demonstrated that geometric morphometrics is a valuable tool for distinguishing cryptic species in hyperdiverse taxonomic groups. These findings not only advance Alpheus taxonomy but also provide tools for studying other marine organisms with subtle morphological differences.

In 2021, we were awarded supplementary funding through the Research Experience for Post-Baccalaureate Students (REPS) program through NSF. For this project, we investigated the evolution of burrowing behavior in the A. brevirostris species group, which includes ~50 burrow-dwelling species known for symbiotic relationships with goby fishes and other taxonomic groups. This study aimed to identify cryptic species, reconstruct phylogenies, and analyze morphological convergence in claw structures that facilitate burrowing lifestyles. DNA sequencing revealed multiple cryptic species and confirmed that burrowing behavior and associated claw morphology have evolved independently multiple times within Alpheus. Distinct claw morphologies, such as longer and thinner claws, may be adaptive for burrowing behaviors and have likely resulted from convergent evolution driven by environmental adaptation.

     This study uniquely integrated genetic, morphological, and ecological data to elucidate patterns of species diversity, and our results have implications for evolutionary biology, marine ecology, and biodiversity. Our findings underscore the evolutionary significance of symbiotic relationships in shaping morphological variation. The comprehensive phylogeny of Alpheus provides a critical framework for future studies, enabling researchers to investigate questions related to speciation, adaptation, and symbiosis on a global scale. Additionally, our findings on burrowing behavior and morphological adaptations shed light on the coevolution of shrimp and their symbiotic partners, such as goby fishes. These associations are among the best-known examples of interspecies communication and cooperation in marine ecosystems.
